At 03:54 04/11/2005, you wrote:
>Ian,
>
>Was not able to follow your "bit encoding" notion (flying through
>things, will re-read later when I can concentrate).
>
>You wrote:
>  > What happens now when individual 1 has just connected C to B' and
>individual 2 has just connected C' to B and they try to breed?
>
>Direct Answer: Within Semiann, when defining the graph for the "combined


Sorry, didn't mean to ask for details about your particular case.  I 
meant to pose it as a philosophical question, e.g. what _should_ we 
do when two individuals are each non-recursive, but the result of 
cross-breeding them would be recursive?

 From your answer I think I take that in your case some of the 
offending connections would be dropped in an arbitrary manner?  And I 
think that stems from the fact that there is an underlying order to 
the nodes which all connection must respect?  So that means that when 
a single order has been determined for the offspring, some 
connections which were valid in the parents will be forbidden in the offspring.

Of course, that means having to test every connection for inclusion 
in the offspring.  I was assuming that if two valid parents were 
cross-bread, then the offspring would automatically be valid.  But 
maybe I was naive on that.

On the other hand, isn't what we have here an example of competing 
conventions?  e.g. no convention was defined in the original 
ancestor, because there was no connection between these two 
"subroutines" but the two current individuals have developed 
different conventions since then.  e.g. a convention of "subnet(BC) 
is a suitable input for subnet(B'C')" or vice-versa.

One way to avoid the generation of this type of competing convention 
is not to use topological analysis to avoid recurrence, but instead 
predetermine which nodes will be acceptable as inputs for which 
others at the time of node creation.  e.g. by assigning each one a 
random real value in the range 0.0 to 1.0 and allowing links only 
where this variable increases.

         Ian


In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
